task_description: Facing the building to your North-East (approx. 47°), estimate the height of the main building in front of you in meters. Answer with one number and a short rationale.

reason: I need to see the building’s roofline and base clearly to estimate total height, so I should tilt the camera upward while keeping the current heading.
The heading is now due north rather than the target north-east, so I should rotate right to about 47° while keeping the upward pitch to view the roofline.
To estimate total height I need the top of the facade/roof in view while staying aligned with the building at ~47°, so I will tilt up.
The view jumped back to heading 0°, so I need to rotate right again to ~47° while keeping the upward pitch to capture the roofline.
Since rotating up keeps resetting the heading, I'll instead move closer to the building to better judge floor count and scale from facade details.
I need to reorient from near-north to the target building at ~47° northeast before estimating its height.
With the building centered, I should tilt up to include the roofline and upper floors for a height estimate.
The heading reset again, so I must rotate right back to ~49° while staying pitched up to view the building top.
Since pitch-up keeps resetting the heading, I'll estimate height from visible facade by moving closer to count stories and use typical story height.
I need to face the building again at ~47° northeast to judge its number of floors and overall scale.
To estimate height reliably I should move closer and get a clearer view of the facade to count stories and compare to nearby elements like doors/trees.
I must rotate from north to about 47° northeast to bring the target building back into view for the height estimate.
At this distance and level view, I can approximate height by counting visible floors of the main block and multiplying by a typical ~3.3 m per story plus roof/parapet.
